taxon.name: earleaf acacia (en)
taxon.id_notes: Distinctive, curved leaf with several parallel midribs (the ‘leaf’ is actually a flattened rachis). A (large?) number of acacia species have a similar seedling form, so if there are two such species planted in the same area, care must be taken. Leaves alternate.
taxon.note: Assuming that the acacia in Haiti is this one, based on various online lists of planting projects. There are several similar species that are hard to tell apart as seedlings (e.g., Acacia mangium).

taxon.name: cashew (en), nwa o pom (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole short. In older seedlings, secondary veins almost perpendicular to midrib. Leaf sometimes reddish.
taxon.note: Native range probably does not include Haiti. Pre-domemestication species from NE Amazon Basin.

taxon.name: soursop (en), korosol (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, elliptic, with glossy upper surface. Secondary veins not visible.
taxon.note: Location of original domestication uncertain.

taxon.name: bullock's heart (en)
taxon.note: This Annona species has fruits ripening flesh-pink, with tesselations on the fruit surface but not protrusions.
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, held disticous in older plants. Leaf elliptic to oblong. Secondary veins impressed into leaf blade.

taxon.name: sweetsop (en), custard apple (en), cashima (ht)
taxon.note: Seems that the Annona grown in Haiti and called cashima is A. squamosa, with the large, rounded protrusions on fruit.
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, held disticous in older plants. Leaf elliptic, light green. Secondary veins appear pale on leaf blade.

taxon.name: breadfruit (en), lam veritab (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, tough, dark-green leaves. Youngest seedlings with serrated leaf margin, soon becoming deeply incised in older plants. This change to incised leaves happens later than in ARTOCAMA
taxon.note: Lam veritab is not generally grown from seed, only cuttings. THTP captures 2021-11-01 to 2021-11-12 are ALTOALTA, verified by Karen Nicolas on 2021-11-12.

taxon.name: breadnut (en), labapen (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, tough, dark-green leaves. Youngest seedlings with serrated leaf margin, soon becoming deeply incised in older plants. This change to incised leaves happens earlier than in ARTOALTA
taxon.note: All Artocarpus in THTP (ht) before Oct 1 2021 were labapen (ARTOCAMA), not lam veritab (ARTOALTA).

taxon.name: neem (in, en), dogoyaro (ng), nim (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets 10 to 30, serrate.
taxon.note: Important in Haiti

Calophyllum species are very hard to ID form leaves - thre are many species and all the leaves look similar except for general size and fine details of the veins. It seems from various documents that the Haiti taxon in plantations is C. calaba, which is not native to the New World (Diaz 2013). Asian C. calaba is a difficult and variable species (Stevens 1980).
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite, secondary veins very fine, dense and parallel.

taxon.name: Colombian mahogany (en), albarco
taxon.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, held in a flat plane, simple; margin strongly wavy. Secondary veins deeply sunken.

taxon.note: It appears from iNaturalist and other resources (e.g., https://phytokeys.pensoft.net/article/49602/ and doi:10.1007/s11676-018-0621-x) that Casuarina equisetifolia is the most common Casuarina in East Africa. restoration: NOTE this can become an invasive under certain circumstances, and should probably not be encouraged.

taxon.name: chèn (ht), Haitian catalpa (en), Jamaican oak (en), Spanish oak (en), yokewood (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite with long, thin peioles. Margin sometimes appearing sometimes coursely serrate but maybe just undulate. Leaves of young seedlings usually with pale yeallow variegation streaks on leaf.

taxon.name: sed (ht), sède (ht), Spanish cedar (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate, with 3-6 opposite leaflets. Secondary veins on leaflets faint, paler than lamina where visible, 5-8 pairs.
taxon.note: commercially important

taxon.name: citrus (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole winged, obovately. Leaf blade obovate, dark green. Secondary veins obsure. Citrus (hybrid) species are difficult to tell apart. Use this genus-level class for most citrus IDs.

taxon.name: sour orange (en), zoranj si (ht)
taxon.id_notes: May be impossible to differentiate from other citrus.
taxon.note: From the ORE website: "Wild sour oranges abound in most of the project areas." This variety may have long become widely naturalized.

taxon.name: key lime (en), citron (ht)
taxon.note: A hybrid: Citrus micrantha × Citrus medica

taxon.name: variegated croton
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate; petioles thick, curved; leaves obovate, veriegated.
taxon.note: Common decorative plant throughout tropics. Appears to be planted in Freetown GS photos (5451a835-162b-481d-8583-aa10c0477ecc)

taxon.name: kokoye (ht), coconut (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves emerge spirally from a hidden apex. Venation palmate.

taxon.name: bwa ple (ht), kapab (ht), greenheart (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, glossy dark green above. Rusty pubescence on twigs and petiole. Tertiary nerves depressed into upper surface of leaf.
taxon.note: Important in Haiti

taxon.name: bwa woz (ht), bwa soumi (ht)
taxon.note: Important in Haiti
taxon.id_notes: Leaves althernate.

taxon.note: Most of these are placed here by inferrence “Cupressus in TZ”

taxon.name: gmelina (en), yemani (sl)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite, broadly ovate, deeply serrate in seedlings, entier in adults.

taxon.name: gliricidia (en), piyon (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets elliptical, entire. Secondary veins obscure.
taxon.note: Important in Haiti

taxon.name: stinking toe (en)
taxon.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Leaflets two, asymmetric.

taxon.note: Similar to CROTMEGA
Misidentified as a Prunus. Most likely a Rubiaceae.
taxon.id_notes: Small, opposite, coriaceous leaves with pale midrib. Longer twigs tend towards growing horizontally; then leaves are held in a single plane.
Leaves palmate. Not clear yet if alternate or opposite.

taxon.name: pacay (ht), ice-cream bean (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. In young seedlings, leaf consists of winged rachis and only two opposite leaflets.
taxon.note: So far (2021-03-23) just making assumption that the Inga in Haiti planting photos is this one.

taxon.name: mango (en, ht)
taxon.note: Can be pruned multiple times for firewood
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole long. Leaves long, leathery, with secondary veins almost perpendicular to the midrib. Compare with cashew.

taxon.name: sapodilla (en), sapoti (ht)
taxon.native_range: Southern Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, elliptic, glossy above. Secondary veins inconspicuous. Compare with ANNOMURI.

taxon.name: Spanish lime (en), kenep (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Rachis of leaves (in young plants?) can be winged and may be confused with Inga.

taxon.name: doliv (ht), moringa (en)
taxon.note: Planted by Forest Nation in Haiti
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, bipinnate. Leaflets oval.

taxon.name: zaboka (ht), avocado (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Tending towards obovate, sometime reddish when young. Very generic tropical tree seedling leaves.
taxon.note: Karen: "Seedlings requires a lot of water the first 3 years". Likely exotic in Haiti: first humans to Haiti ~1,200 AD, well after avocado was domesticated.

taxon.name: camel's foot (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, simple. Leaf apex deeply cleft.

taxon.note: In Tanzania, the main restoration Pinus species appears to be Pinus patula Schltdl. & Cham., a native of Mexico. Most of the images are placed here by inferrence “Pinus in TZ”

taxon.name: bayawonn (ht)
taxon.native_range: Mexico, South America and the Caribbean
taxon.note: Important in Haiti

taxon.name: guava (en)
taxon.native_range: Caribbean, Central America and South America
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite. Secondary veins deeply sunken into leaf (from above).

taxon.name: siamese cassia, kassod (en), kasya (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite, 6-16, elliptic. Secondary veins obscure. Leaflets similar to GLIRSEPI, but leaf without a terminal leaflet.
taxon.note: Previously called Cassia siamea.
Important in Haiti.

taxon.sci_name: Simarouba glauca DC. var. latifolia Cronq.
taxon.name: bwa fwenn (ht), bwa blan (ht), doliv (ht), simarouba (en), princess tree (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets alternate, 6-7 pairs.

taxon.name: mahogany (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Secondary veins sunken.
taxon.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.

taxon.name: tamarind (en), tamren (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite on rachis, in 7-8 pairs, oblong in shape.

taxon.name: sea almond (en), zanmann (ht), ketapang (id)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, obovate. Young seedlings still show the first pair of kidney-shaped leaves.

taxon.name: ronko (sl), bagyi (sl), idigbo (en)
taxon.note: There are many Terminalia native to West Africa, plus the ubiquitous T. catappa, and most Terminalia are similar as seedlings. Inferrence (weak): {local name from Freetown planters = ronko} + {ronko in online wood database = T. ivorensis} + {images = terminalia} => {images in Freetown = T. ivorensis}.

taxon.name: cacao (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole narrow, at an angle to plane of leaf, and swollen ‘knee’ at petiole apex. Leaves large, dark-green, with strongly curving secondary veins. Older plants show a ‘V’ pair of basal secondary veins, but these are less obvious in the smaller plants.

country.note:
1. from https://www.theevertree.com/haiti "Agroforestry Species" Gliricidia sepium Leucaena leucocephala Lysiloma sabicu Benth. Roystonea borinquena Senna siamea Swietenia mahagoni
2. from Landscape Factors and Restoration Practices Associated with Initial Reforestation Success in Haiti Starry D. Sprenkle-Hyppolite et al. Azadirachta indica, neem, "nim" Enterolobium cyclocarpum, “bwa taniswouj” Eucalyptus camaldulensis, “ekiliptus”
1. spreadsheet for Freetown from Zaven: Jackfruit Artocarpus heterophyllus Albizia zygia Albizia zygia Flame of the forest Delonix regia Ronko/Baggi Terminalia ivorensis TROPICAL ALMOND

## Usambaras
Usambara species from https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0250859 (via KNB): Albizia gummifera, Albizia sp, Allanblackia stuhlmannii, Allophyllus melliodorus, Anisophyllea obtusifolia, Annickia kummeriae, Anthocleista grandiflora, Antiaris toxicaria, Bersama abyssinica, Blighia unijugata, Bridelia micrantha, Cedrela odorata, Celtis gomphophylla, Cephalosphaera usambarensis, Chrysophyllum perpulchrum, Cinnamomum camphora, Cussonia zimmermannii, Drypetes gerrardii, Ficus altissima, Ficus natalensis, Ficus sp., Ficus sp. [strangler], Ficus sp. [triangular leaves], Greenwayodendron suaveolens, Grevillea robusta, Harungana madagascariensis, Macaranga capensis, Maesa lanceolata, Maesopsis eminii, Maranthes goetzeniana, Newtonia buchananii, Odyendea zimmermannii, Parinari excelsa, Polyscias fulva, Psidium guajava, Rauvolfia caffra, Rhodognaphalon schumannianum, Rinorea ilicifolia, Rubiaceae sp, Rubiaceae sp2, Sapium ellipticum, Sorindeia madagascariensis, Strombosia scheffleri, Synsepalum cerasiferum, Syzygium guineense, Tricalysia sp., Trichilia dregeana, Trichilia emetica, Trilepisium madagascariense, unknown, unknown spp 1, Xylopia aethiopica, Xymalos monospora, Zanha golungensis, Zanthoxylum usambarense

gs_taxa.doc: Timyam, Joel. 1996. Bwa Yo: Important Trees of Haiti. South-East Consortium for International Development.
